DOC.HEAD: US Ambassador Frees $25,000 for Food, Medicine in Panama
With AM-US-Panama Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. ambassador to Panama, Arthur Davis, has authorized $25,000 to purchase food and medicine for needy Panamanians, the State Department said Friday. In addition, as part of the restoration of normal relations with Panama, the Treasury Department released $100,000 in Panamanian funds which had been frozen in the United States, department spokesman Richard Boucher said. The frozen funds were to be turned over to President Guillermo Endara for payment of salaries, officials said. The $25,000 came from a fund the embassy maintains for emergency situations, Boucher said. Panama's assets in the United States were frozen last year. The total is estimated at $371 million. Meanwhile, Panama's new ambassador to Washington, Carlos Rodriguez, moved into the embassy on Friday. The keys to the mission were turned over to him by a State Department official in late afternoon. The embassy was shut down Sept. 1, the date on which the term of office expired of President Eric Arturo Delvalle. The Bush administration regarded Delvalle as Panama's legitimate authority even though he had been ousted in February 1988.
